Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Story: It was Saturday afternoon when my phone buzzed with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Call us when you can!” I smiled, feeling a familiar warmth, but also a twinge of guilt—I hadn’t called home in over a week. I knew how much it meant to my parents to hear from me, especially on weekends. I started typing a quick reply, promising to call later, when another notification popped up. It was Jamie, an acquaintance from work. “Hey, sorry to bother you, but my car broke down on Maple Road. Could you help me out?” I stared at the two messages, my thumb hovering uncertainly. I wanted to be the reliable daughter who checked in, but Jamie sounded stranded and anxious. I could almost hear my mom’s gentle disappointment if I put off calling again, but I also imagined Jamie waiting alone, hoping someone would come. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—family connection versus being a supportive acquaintance—feeling pulled in two directions, unsure which need to answer first.
